Award.AwardTitle: Computational analysis of nonlinear electromagnetics in disordered photonic systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Physicists have known for centuries how to predict the behavior of light and other types of electromagnetic radiation when it moves through a vacuum, using Maxwell's Laws; however, when it propagates through disorderly media, like those we use in developing new engineering devices, people have relied on very gross approximations or back-of-the-envelope estimates to predict what will happen. These PIs will develop new computer simulation systems to predict what happens more accurately than has been possible in the past. Their new tools should be of very widespread use, in photonics and electrooptics, in developing new devices and technologies. They plan to disseminate the new software widely to enable scientists worldwide to conduct research on this topic.

The project will focus on developing an integrated solver for self-consistent Maxwell-Bloch equations that is accurate and computationally efficient. This will entail the development of (1) a domain decomposition framework; (2) semi-analytical methods for transient analysis of radiation/scattering; and (3) fast potential evaluators that can be integrated with these solvers to enable large-scale analysis of disordered systems. The framework will provide a complete picture of the dynamics of light and optical excitations (excitons) in a variety of disordered systems, starting with Vertical Cavity Surface Emitting Laser (VCSEL) structures with disorder. Another system to be investigated as a testbed is the case of quantum dots embedded in a semiconductor with and without an external cavity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit 

The principal goal of this project was to develop innovative methods to enable accurate analysis of disordered photonic systems. The principal intellectual outcome was a suite of publicly available software tools, several scientific publications, and a Ph. D. dissertation.

Within this project, we developed the first release of a Quantum Electromagnetics Simulation Toolbox (QuEST) software (available under a GNU general public license). In QuEST, we have implemented new fast algorithms for solving time dependent integral equations that describe laser propagation in media with a high density of active optical centers. As a scientific endeavor, QuEST largely emphasizes reproducibility, ease of extension, and execution speed. The software has been widely disseminated to enable scientists worldwide to conduct research in this area.

A novel integral formulation of Maxwell Bloch equations provided the key mathematical tool to model the optical response of disordered photonic systems. Using QuEST, we have been able to solve Maxwell Bloch equations in systems containing up to 105 active centers. Specifically, we have simulated materials containing quantum dots, which are semiconductor nanoparticles that behave like atoms but are characterized by a much stronger light-matter coupling. Fig. 1 shows an example in which we simulated quantum dots in a cylinder under the effect of a laser pulse propagating from left to right. These simulations have allowed us to better understand the interplay between randomness and localization of the electric field in these systems. We have identified several local field effects that would not have been observed using average field-methods. We also have been able to simulate how light would propagate in yet to be made complex optical materials with heterogeneous mixtures of active centers. An example of simulated light propagation in a heterogeneous optical material is shown in Fig. 2. Simulations like the one in Fig. 2 allowed us to explore effects due to variation in quantum dot size. We have found, for instance, that the localization of the electric field can be strongly suppressed by the presence of a inhomogeneous broadening of the resonance frequency of the dots.

Broader Impacts 

We expect that the work in this proposal will facilitate the design of novel optical materials with enhanced properties. This would impact many areas of science and technology, leading to new lasers, better components for photonics, and to a deeper understanding of how light interacts with matter. More specifically, the broader impacts of the work undertaken include: (a) public release of a code suite; (b) use of the code suite beyond photonics, e.g. in nano-magnetic simulations; (c) training and mentoring of undergraduate students and (d) graduation of a Ph.D student.

The supported graduate student (Dr. Connor Glosser) has also assisted in the Michigan Tech Mind Trekkers program performing scientific demonstrations for K-12 students, and has given several interactive seminars on scientific programming in local high school physics classes. He is currently working for MathWorks to develop software for the autonomous car research and development, contributing to Michigan's automotive industry development.
